newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore HSFO seen stuck in a $115-$118/T range.
newsitem.headline: Singapore HSFO seen stuck in a $115-$118/T range.

text.p: High sulphur fuel oil prices on Thursday were expected to be stuck in a similar range as Wednesday with most traders mixed on market direction.
Bid/asked for cash 180-cst supplies for October loading were at $115-$118 per tonne, while Wednesday's was $115-$117.
Some traders said while prices might climb further on Chinese demand, the upside is limited.
"China has been buying a lot of supplies from South Korea and Japan but not from Singapore" said a Japanese trader.
Bids have been heard around $128 a tonne for cargoes to be delivered to China in October, he said.
"While demand from China may have risen, stocks in this region has also increased," said another trader.
Residues stocks in Singapore rose 519,000 barrels to 9.737 million barrels, according to statistics released by the Trade Development Board of Singapore.
Traders said there are increased MidEast supplies seen heading eastwards with around four cargoes from Kuwait.
Some sources said Kuwait has already sold five cargoes of 380-cst supplies in October at around $2 a tonne premium to Singapore quotes on a cost-and-freight basis.
Pockets of demand were seen from Vietnam, Thailand and Indonesia, which could help support Singapore prices, they said.
October paper was bid/asked at $115.25-$116.25, below Wednesday's quotes at $115.50-$116.50, tracking crude losses.
